question_content.barrons:question: The author’s attitude towards Lind’s experiment can best be described as one of
question_content.barrons:explanation:
qualified appreciation.

The author appreciates many aspects of Lind’s experiment (he enumerates its "obvious commendable features"). However, his appreciation is qualified: he limits his approbation, approving those aspects of the experiment that he finds commendable and pointing out other aspects of the experiment that do not meet with his approval.

Measured indignation is incorrect. While the author does have some critical comments to make about Lind’s experiment, his attitude towards it is not one of measured indignation (restrained righteous anger).

Wholehearted admiration is incorrect. The author makes critical comments about Lind’s experiment. His attitude towards it is not one of wholehearted admiration (earnest approval).

Resigned forebearance is incorrect. While the author does have some critical comments to make about Lind’s experiment, his attitude towards it is not one of resigned forbearance (philosophical patient endurance).

Fulsome adulation is incorrect. The author makes critical comments about Lind’s experiment. His attitude towards it is not one of fulsome adulation (excessively overdone admiration).
